meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Monday 2026-01-26 in Rockford, MI: no new snow or precip is forecast (0"), and winds are modest (max ~16 mph). The main concern is extreme cold and wind chills (feels like around -7°F near daybreak) plus episodes of very low visibility overnight/early morning (forecast vis occasionally 0–1 mile), which can be consistent with fog/ice fog. Michigan schools typically do not close for cold alone, and with no accumulating snow and manageable winds, a snow day is unlikely; however, a brief delay is possible if dense fog/ice fog reduces visibility and creates localized slick spots from residual moisture/freezing (especially after tonight’s wintry mix).

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Post-front Arctic high pressure / cold-dry day: light snow/freezing drizzle the prior evening, then Monday turns dry with overcast and steady NW winds (10–16 mph) and temps in the single digits to mid-teens.

Cold with modest wind chills but no blizzard conditions: morning wind chills roughly near/just below 0°F (e.g., -7°F around 5 AM; near 0°F around 7–9 AM), improving only slightly through midday as temps rise into the teens.

Visibility-limited pockets (radiational/low-level haze/fog) overnight into early morning (several hours showing 0–2 km / 0–1 mile visibility) without falling snow—can create localized slick spots but usually not system-wide shutdown criteria.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly supports subfreezing days, with periodic lake-effect snow and occasional arctic air intrusions. A dry day with highs in the teens and lows near/just above 0°F is cold but not rare for this time of year; closures are usually driven by active snowfall, ice storms, or extreme wind chills rather than just cold temperatures.
unusual_factors: No measurable snow is forecast for Monday (0.0"), which strongly lowers closure odds even with cold temps.

Overnight/early-morning visibility is modeled very low at times (0–1 mile or less), which can be impactful if it coincides with untreated roads or blowing/drifting—but winds are only moderate and there is no snow falling to drive true whiteout.

There was light freezing rain/light snow reported Sunday evening (2026-01-25) with a Winter Weather Advisory in parts of the NWS Grand Rapids area; any leftover glaze/compaction could create isolated slick spots Monday morning even though Monday itself is dry.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits close enough to Lake Michigan influence that lake-effect can matter when winds are W/NW, but Monday’s forecast shows no snow production—suggesting limited lake-effect moisture/instability in this setup.
Low-lying river valleys/nearby rural pockets can run a bit colder at night and can see more localized fog/ice patches than main roads.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan road commissions and districts typically handle cold, light snow well; without accumulating snow during the commute window, widespread closures are less common.
If there was any Sunday-evening glaze or light snow compaction, the Monday morning risk shifts to 'spotty slick intersections/bridges' rather than 'impassable roads.'
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor-to-moderate: small elevation changes around Rockford can create patchy drifting and icy pockets, but with 0 snow forecast and only moderate winds, elevation effects are unlikely to be closure-driving.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day likelihood for Monday, 2026-01-26 is low. The forecast is cold (high ~15°F, low ~2°F) with steady winds, but it is notably dry (0 precip/snow) and lacks the classic Michigan closure triggers (heavy snow 8–10+ inches timed to the commute, significant ice, blizzard/whiteout, or extreme wind chills below about -15°F). The main 'watch item' is residual slickness from Sunday evening’s light freezing rain/snow and the modeled early-morning visibility dips; these more often lead to slower travel or a delay in isolated cases rather than a widespread closure.

safety_recommendations: Overall snow-day likelihood: LOW for Monday, 2026-01-26 (normal operations likely), but expect a cold start and localized slick spots.
Main risk is refreeze/black ice from Sunday evening’s light wintry mix plus very cold pavement temps overnight; treat bridges/overpasses, shaded areas, and rural segments as higher risk.

Visibility is the limiting factor overnight into the early commute (reported around ~1 mile at times, and even briefly near zero in the data). Use reduced speeds and longer following distances for buses and parent drop-off traffic.

Prioritize early-morning treatment (salt/brine where effective, abrasives where too cold) on school-zone approaches, hills, intersections, and known trouble spots; verify conditions on secondary roads used by bus routes.
Address pedestrian risk: extreme cold/wind chills around the morning commute increase slip-and-fall and exposure risk at stops—encourage bundled layers, face/hand coverage, and minimizing wait times.
Have facilities crew check and spot-treat parking lots/sidewalks before staff arrival; refreeze is most likely before/around sunrise.
Communications trigger: if district spotters report widespread glare ice on untreated neighborhood roads at 5:30–6:30 AM, consider a delay rather than closure (plows/treatment can catch up).

The main operational risk is NOT deep snow, but refreeze/black ice from Sunday’s light freezing rain/light snow and very cold overnight temps. Snow day likelihood due to road impassability alone looks low to moderate; a DELAY is more plausible than a full closure if early-morning icy patches are widespread on neighborhood/bus pickup streets.

Snow-day likelihood Monday is low based on your forecast (no accumulating snow/ice expected Monday), but consider cold-exposure policies for bus stops and morning operations.

critical_alerts.message: AUTOMATIC CLOSURE TRIGGER MET on at least one public source: Weather.com hourly shows 'Feels Like' around -23°F to -24°F (below -20°F). This requires immediate re-check closer to the school decision window.

Major discrepancy: WeatherAPI Monday 2026-01-26 minimum hourly feels-like is about -6.8°F, but one Weather.com listing shows about -23°F to -24°F (difference > 10°F). This is a conflicting forecast signal.

Weather.com results appear inconsistent across different Rockford hourly URLs (some show extreme cold; another shows much milder/snowy-windy conditions). This reduces confidence in using a single Weather.com page as the source of truth without re-checking the correct day/location view.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For Monday 2026-01-26 in Rockford, MI (49341), your WeatherAPI forecast shows cold but not closure-threshold wind chills (lowest hourly feels-like ~ -6.8°F around 5 AM, with daytime feels-like generally near 0°F to a few degrees above/below). However, at least one Weather.com hourly listing for Rockford, MI 49341 shows much colder conditions with 'Feels Like' values around -23°F to -24°F during the early morning hours—below the -20°F automatic-closure trigger. Because public Weather.com pages also show conflicting Rockford hour-by-hour outputs across different URLs, the web-source picture is inconsistent. With this level of disagreement, the safest operational stance is that the -20°F trigger cannot be ruled out based on public-facing app data, and a re-check using Weather.gov (NWS point forecast / hourly wind chill) and AccuWeather (RealFeel) is required as the decision window approaches.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist:
1) Agreement: All experts agree Monday is mostly dry with no meaningful new snowfall; the main hazards are residual slick spots (refreeze/black ice) and potentially low visibility (ice fog). They also agree a delay is more plausible than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: The only major conflict is wind chill—WeatherAPI bottoms near ~-7°F, but one Weather.com view suggests ≤-20°F. Web verifier re-check still shows inconsistent Weather.com variants and could not confirm NWS hourly in this environment, so this remains unresolved.
3) Plow timing math: Precip ended Sun evening; there are ~12+ hours until ~6:30 AM. That is typically enough time for highways/arterials to become serviceable, but *also enough time for refreeze* to keep residential/secondary roads icy. Infrastructure monitor expects arterials mostly passable by 06:30–08:00 with localized black ice; residential streets most likely still icy.
4) Ice?: Yes, moderate risk (refreeze/black ice) due to earlier light freezing rain/light snow and very cold temps. Not an active ice storm Monday.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel found no verified closures/delays for Rockford, Forest Hills, Northview, Sparta, Lowell, Kentwood, or GRPS for 1/26—no upward adjustment.
6) Power outages: Minimal currently (~68 systemwide in Consumers snapshot); no sign of a local outage-driven closure.
7) Wind chill verification: Not confirmed by multiple reliable sources. One Weather.com page hits ≤-20°F, but other pages + WeatherAPI do not, and NWS couldn’t be checked here; therefore I cannot apply the near-automatic closure rule.
8) What would make me wrong: (a) If NWS hourly/observations confirm wind chill ≤-20°F near 6–8 AM, closure probability jumps into the 90% range; (b) if widespread dense ice fog (≤0.25 mi) or widespread glare ice on neighborhood/bus-route roads is observed at 5:30–6:30 AM, many districts could call a 2-hr delay or even close.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology (25%) + Safety (20%) + History (15%) + News (15%) + Infrastructure (10%) + Power (10%) + Web verifier (5%). Base closure odds on a cold/dry day with residual slickness are low (history 7–15%). Safety suggests full closure ~10% and delay ~35%. Infrastructure supports “arterials ok / residential still icy,” consistent with delay-not-closure. News shows no closure signals. Power is not a driver.

Given all that, I set full snow-day (closure) probability at 14% (low, but not zero). Most disruption risk is better represented as a *2-hour delay* scenario rather than full closure. Confidence is moderate because the wind-chill and visibility signals are not authoritatively resolved here.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Normal on-time opening with caution advisories (most likely)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Buses run; emphasize reduced speeds and extra time at icy stops/bridges; spot-treat lots/sidewalks early.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: 2-hour delay due to widespread patchy black ice on residential/secondary roads and/or ice fog 0.25–1.0 mi
alternative_scenarios.impact: Gives road crews daylight and time for sanding; reduces bus-stop exposure time in extreme cold.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure triggered by confirmed wind chill ≤ -20°F and/or widespread dense ice fog (≤0.25 mi) plus icy roads
alternative_scenarios.impact: District-wide shutdown; highest safety margin if conditions verify worse than forecast.

for_schools: Plan for normal operations but pre-authorize a rapid 05:45–06:15 AM decision for a 2-hour delay if spotters report widespread glare ice on bus-route neighborhood roads.
Conduct pre-dawn spot checks on known trouble areas: bridges/overpasses, hills, shaded rural connectors, subdivision turnarounds, and school-zone intersections.
If wind chill is confirmed (via NWS hourly/observations) at or below -20°F during 06:00–08:00, strongly consider closure per bus-stop exposure policy.
Send a parent/staff note emphasizing icy patches + cold: layered clothing, minimize bus-stop wait times, and allow extra travel time.
Have facilities crews prioritize sidewalks/entries/parking lots with abrasives (salt effectiveness limited in very cold temps).
for_residents: Assume patchy black ice: slow down, increase following distance, and be cautious on bridges/ramps and in neighborhoods.
If you see dense fog/ice fog, use low beams and avoid passing; expect sudden visibility drops in low spots/river valleys.
Dress for near/below-zero wind chills; limit time waiting outdoors and keep phones charged.
for_authorities: Prioritize sanding/abrasives over salt in the coldest hours; focus on intersections, hills, and bridges before 06:30.
If visibility drops materially, consider targeted messaging and patrols on known fog-prone corridors.
Monitor for any overnight outage clustering; ensure warming center readiness if outages expand in extreme cold.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Monday (2026-01-26) looks like an arctic/overcast, dry day. With 0 new snow/ice expected and only moderate winds, the classic closure triggers (heavy snow during commute, ice storm, blizzard conditions) are absent. The two meteorology-driven risks are (1) very low visibility overnight into early morning (possible ice fog) and (2) cold wind chills—both of which can pressure a delay decision if they coincide with untreated roads and bus-route problem spots. On balance, that supports a low-but-nonzero snow-day probability, leaning toward delays rather than closure. I set 12% for full closure; I’d set a higher probability for a 1–2 hour delay if that were a separate question.
keyFactors: No forecast accumulation on Mon 2026-01-26 (0" snow, 0 precip) strongly argues against a full closure.
Winds are only modest (sustained ~6–15 mph; gusts mostly ~15–25 mph daytime, higher late evening). This limits blowing/drifting/whiteout risk.

Cold is notable (low ~2–6°F; wind chills roughly -7°F to near 0°F around the AM commute per WeatherAPI), but that’s typically *not* enough by itself for a closure in West Michigan absent heavy snow/ice or extreme wind chills (e.g., below ~-15 to -20°F).

Visibility is the main meteorological “wild card”: several overnight hours show 0–1 mile and even 0 mi in the feed, which could indicate ice fog or low stratus/fog. If real and widespread during 6–9 AM, it can produce hazardous bus conditions and a delay—but usually not a districtwide closure by itself.

Residual impacts from Sun 2026-01-25 light snow/freezing rain could refreeze hard overnight given very cold pavement temps. That increases *delay* odds more than closure odds, but it’s not a Monday-forecast meteorology signal (it’s a carryover/road-treatment issue).

positions.rationale: As the history specialist, I weight base-rate behavior: in late January, a cold, post-system, dry Monday in West Michigan has a low closure rate. The main ways this becomes a snow day are (a) widespread glare ice from the prior evening that overwhelms overnight treatment, or (b) wind-chill policies being tripped by an *actual* sub -20°F wind chill forecast/observation. Given the provided WeatherAPI hourly wind chills bottom out around roughly -7°F and winds are moderate, the base case is normal operations. I assign ~10% to account for the ‘tail risk’ that residual ice + localized near-zero visibility (ice fog) is more widespread than modeled, prompting a closure rather than a delay.
keyFactors: Historical closure triggers in West Michigan are usually *active* heavy snow during the commute, significant ice accretion, blizzard/whiteout, or truly extreme wind chills; Monday’s forecast is cold but *dry* (0 precip / 0 snow) with only modest winds (~10–16 mph).
Cold alone (even single digits/teens) rarely produces full closures in this region; it’s more likely to produce “dress warm / limit time at stops” messaging than a snow day.

Residual impacts from Sunday evening’s light freezing rain/light snow could create patchy black ice Monday morning, but that typically maps to a **delay** decision (or targeted bus-route adjustments) rather than district-wide closure when there’s no new precip falling Monday.

Modeled overnight visibility dips (0–1 mile or less for several hours) are a nonzero historical risk factor, but without falling/blowing snow and with moderate winds, it’s usually localized and short-lived—again, more “delay/caution” than “cancel.”

No strong district-signal/news chatter indicating a planned closure for Monday 2026-01-26 (weak but relevant historical indicator: closures often show up by late evening/early AM when a major event is expected).

positions.rationale: From a safety perspective, I’m not seeing an all-day, system-wide travel hazard (no accumulating snow, no active icing event Monday). The most plausible operational disruption is a **2-hour delay** if early-morning spot checks find widespread glare ice on neighborhood/bus-pickup roads or if dense ice fog materially reduces visibility during the bus window. A full closure would require either (a) much more significant, widespread ice than implied by the very light wintry mix, or (b) an extreme wind-chill policy trigger being met region-wide. That second pathway is uncertain because one web verifier flagged a conflicting, much colder ‘feels like’ (-20s °F), but the provided WeatherAPI hourly wind chills are not close to that threshold. Balancing these, I land at a low-to-low-moderate closure probability, with most of that probability mass actually representing “delay-worthy” morning hazards rather than a true snow day.
keyFactors: No new precip expected Monday (0" snow / 0" liquid) and winds are only modest–breezy (generally 6–15 mph, gusts ~20–40 mph late), which usually supports normal operations.

Safety risk is dominated by **refreeze/black ice** potential from Sunday’s light freezing rain/light snow and very cold pavement temps overnight (lows near ~2–6°F). This can produce hazardous *spot* conditions on untreated residential streets, bridges/overpasses, shaded curves, and parking lots/sidewalks—more consistent with a **delay** than a full closure.

Visibility is the other meaningful risk: multiple overnight/early hours show **0–1 mile or even 0** visibility (likely fog/ice fog or reporting artifact). If that persists into the 6–8 AM bus window, it can materially increase crash risk even without falling snow.

Cold exposure at bus stops is non-trivial (wind chills roughly -5 to 0°F per WeatherAPI), but in this region cold alone is rarely a closure trigger unless wind chills are much lower and/or coupled with other hazards.
No strong “district is already closing” signal in the news/announcement scan, which lowers odds of a proactive closure.

positions.rationale: From a news/ops standpoint, the strongest predictors are (a) what districts are signaling publicly and (b) whether there’s a clear regionwide hazard (active snow/ice event, widespread advisory/warning impacting the district, major crashes/outages). As of Sun 2026-01-25, Rockford Public Schools’ site shows no 1/26 closure/delay announcement, and I did not see neighboring-district closure signals either. Weather for Mon is cold but dry (no new accumulation), which typically does not generate same-day closures in West Michigan. The main realistic disruption would be a late decision for a **1–2 hour delay** if early-morning black ice/ice fog proves widespread on secondary roads. That keeps the full “snow day” probability low but non-zero.
keyFactors: No official closure/delay posted by Rockford Public Schools as of Sun 2026-01-25 evening; neighboring districts likewise show no verified 1/26 closure signal.
Forecast for Mon 2026-01-26 shows **0 precip / 0 snow** and only moderate winds—news-pattern-wise, that usually correlates with “normal operations,” not a full closure.

Main plausible headline risk is **overnight refreeze/black ice + occasional very low visibility (0–1 mi, even 0 in the feed)** during the bus/commute window, which more often triggers a **delay** than a closure.

NWS alerts in the dataset are **not aimed at Kent County/Rockford for Monday** (flood advisory is Newaygo County and expires Sun 7 PM; winter weather advisory is SW counties and expires Sun night). That reduces “regionwide closure” momentum.

Conflicting public-web wind chill signals (one Weather.com view indicating sub -20°F wind chills) create some uncertainty, but those sources appear inconsistent/out-of-date; without corroboration from NWS/official district comms, I’m not pricing an “automatic cold closure” highly.

debates.topic: The visibility signal includes several hours listed at 0 miles—this could be a sensor/model artifact in the feed rather than true dense fog. We should treat it as a risk flag, but not overweight it without corroboration (e.g., METARs / NWS hourly visibility).

debates.challenge: News agent indicates no closure announcements as of Sun evening, which is helpful, but districts often decide early AM for marginal ‘black ice/fog’ scenarios. Lack of pre-announcement should not be treated as strong evidence against a delay/closure.

debates.topic: Safety analysis leans ‘moderate’ impact 01:00–08:00; I agree on refreeze/black ice potential, but that’s not directly supported by Monday precip fields. It depends heavily on how much glaze/compaction actually occurred Sunday evening and road treatment overnight—so it should be presented as conditional rather than expected.

debates.topic: Historical pattern rates (7–15%) feel reasonable, but ensure we don’t double-count the same drivers (cold + low vis) when converting to a single closure probability. The base rate for a *full closure* on a dry, cold day is likely closer to the low end unless wind chills become truly extreme.

debates.topic: WEBWEATHERVERIFIER shows a large wind chill discrepancy versus WeatherAPI (some pages claiming -23 to -24°F). That could be wrong-location/wrong-time or stale crawl, but if true it materially changes closure odds. We need a single authoritative point forecast verification close to decision time.

debates.topic: The 0–1 mile (even 0) visibility hours are a potential over-signal or artifact. Can you sanity-check whether the visibility minima align with dewpoint depressions / expected ice fog conditions, and whether it overlaps the 6–9 AM bus window enough to matter district-wide?
debates.challenge: The 0–1 mile (even 0) visibility hours are a potential over-signal or artifact. Can you sanity-check whether the visibility minima align with dewpoint depressions / expected ice fog conditions, and whether it overlaps the 6–9 AM bus window enough to matter district-wide?

debates.topic: Your risk framing leans ‘moderate’ due to refreeze. Historically, districts close when *most* bus-route neighborhood roads are compromised, not just bridges/intersections. Do we have evidence that untreated residentials will be broadly icy (vs patchy) given no new precip Monday? If not, the decision tends to a delay.

debates.topic: I’m cautious about treating ‘no announcement yet’ as meaningful the night before—some districts decide very early AM. If you can, confirm whether Rockford’s typical decision cadence is night-before vs morning-of in similar cold/dry setups.
debates.challenge: I’m cautious about treating ‘no announcement yet’ as meaningful the night before—some districts decide very early AM. If you can, confirm whether Rockford’s typical decision cadence is night-before vs morning-of in similar cold/dry setups.

debates.topic: WebWeatherVerifier shows a conflicting extreme wind chill scenario (below -20°F) on at least one Weather.com page. Historically, if official NWS hourly wind chill forecasts were truly that low, closures/delays become much more likely. Can we reconcile which source is correct (location mismatch / stale cache / unit conversion), and what NWS point forecast indicates?

debates.topic: Our news signal is thin (no buzz, no closures). If there’s a credible source of early-morning closure chatter (local TV closure tickers, district socials), it should be added—otherwise we should resist raising probability on speculation.

debates.topic: WebWeatherVerifier flags sub -20°F wind chills from Weather.com, but with inconsistent URLs and stale crawls; we need a reliable tie-breaker (ideally NWS hourly wind chill) before treating that as an ‘automatic closure trigger.’
debates.challenge: WebWeatherVerifier flags sub -20°F wind chills from Weather.com, but with inconsistent URLs and stale crawls; we need a reliable tie-breaker (ideally NWS hourly wind chill) before treating that as an ‘automatic closure trigger.’

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, Monday (2026-01-26) looks like an arctic/overcast, dry day. With 0 new snow/ice expected and only moderate winds, the classic closure triggers (heavy snow during commute, ice storm, blizzard conditions) are absent. The two meteorology-driven risks are (1) very low visibility overnight into early morning (possible ice fog) and (2) cold wind chills—both of which can pressure a delay decision if they coincide with untreated roads and bus-route problem spots. On balance, that supports a low-but-nonzero snow-day probability, leaning toward delays rather than closure. I set 12% for full closure; I’d set a higher probability for a 1–2 hour delay if that were a separate question.

As the history specialist, I weight base-rate behavior: in late January, a cold, post-system, dry Monday in West Michigan has a low closure rate. The main ways this becomes a snow day are (a) widespread glare ice from the prior evening that overwhelms overnight treatment, or (b) wind-chill policies being tripped by an *actual* sub -20°F wind chill forecast/observation. Given the provided WeatherAPI hourly wind chills bottom out around roughly -7°F and winds are moderate, the base case is normal operations. I assign ~10% to account for the ‘tail risk’ that residual ice + localized near-zero visibility (ice fog) is more widespread than modeled, prompting a closure rather than a delay.

From a safety perspective, I’m not seeing an all-day, system-wide travel hazard (no accumulating snow, no active icing event Monday). The most plausible operational disruption is a **2-hour delay** if early-morning spot checks find widespread glare ice on neighborhood/bus-pickup roads or if dense ice fog materially reduces visibility during the bus window. A full closure would require either (a) much more significant, widespread ice than implied by the very light wintry mix, or (b) an extreme wind-chill policy trigger being met region-wide. That second pathway is uncertain because one web verifier flagged a conflicting, much colder ‘feels like’ (-20s °F), but the provided WeatherAPI hourly wind chills are not close to that threshold. Balancing these, I land at a low-to-low-moderate closure probability, with most of that probability mass actually representing “delay-worthy” morning hazards rather than a true snow day.

From a news/ops standpoint, the strongest predictors are (a) what districts are signaling publicly and (b) whether there’s a clear regionwide hazard (active snow/ice event, widespread advisory/warning impacting the district, major crashes/outages). As of Sun 2026-01-25, Rockford Public Schools’ site shows no 1/26 closure/delay announcement, and I did not see neighboring-district closure signals either. Weather for Mon is cold but dry (no new accumulation), which typically does not generate same-day closures in West Michigan. The main realistic disruption would be a late decision for a **1–2 hour delay** if early-morning black ice/ice fog proves widespread on secondary roads. That keeps the full “snow day” probability low but non-zero.

keyDisagreements.topic: The visibility signal includes several hours listed at 0 miles—this could be a sensor/model artifact in the feed rather than true dense fog. We should treat it as a risk flag, but not overweight it without corroboration (e.g., METARs / NWS hourly visibility).
positions: The visibility signal includes several hours listed at 0 miles—this could be a sensor/model artifact in the feed rather than true dense fog. We should treat it as a risk flag, but not overweight it without corroboration (e.g., METARs / NWS hourly visibility).

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 24 at 2:30PM EST until January 25 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...Along the Muskegon River in Newaygo County, downriver of
Croton Dam, around the city of Newaygo and toward Bridgeton

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Low lying areas along the Muskegon River that are prone
to flooding may see rapidly changing water levels.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 215 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Saturday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. Flooding due
to freeze-up ice jams is typically minor, but can be
unpredictable.
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 25 at 12:15PM EST until January 25 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch.

* WHERE...Eaton, Barry, Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 10 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Occasional snow can be expected this
afternoon. The snow will wind down this evening.
alert.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling.
